97602.name: Urban population (US Census Bureau (2010))
97602.description: When the US Census Bureau first defined urban places in the 1880 and 1890 censuses, an urban place was one which had a minimum population of 4,000 to 8,000 people. This threshold rose to a population of 2,500 for the 1910 census, rising again to a population of 50,000 or more by the 1950 census.
97602.datasetName: Urban and rural populations in the United States - US Census Bureau (2010)

source.name: US Census Bureau (2010)
source.additionalInfo: For further information on the US Census Bureau's urban and rural classifications see: https://www.census.gov/geo/reference/ua/uafaq.html or https://www.census.gov/geo/reference/ua/urban-rural-2010.html

97603.name: Rural population (US Census Bureau (2010))
97603.description:
When the US Census Bureau first defined urban places in the 1880 and 1890 censuses, an urban place was one which had a minimum population of 4,000 to 8,000 people. This threshold rose to a population of 2,500 for the 1910 census, rising again to a population of 50,000 or more by the 1950 census.

The rural population is defined as any population outside urban areas.
97603.datasetName: Urban and rural populations in the United States - US Census Bureau (2010)

source.name: US Census Bureau (2010)
source.additionalInfo: For further information on the US Census Bureau's urban and rural classifications see: https://www.census.gov/geo/reference/ua/uafaq.html or https://www.census.gov/geo/reference/ua/urban-rural-2010.html
